title: Cross Site Scripting (Stored)

profile.name: ExpressionEngine
profile.about: ExpressionEngine is a robust and flexible open-source Content Management System.

vulnerability_information: Occurred in the URL : https://store.ellislab.com/billing After adding a product to the cart proceed to add the billing and card information and in the card fields give your card details respectively and in the fields 1. First name 2. Last name 3. Street Address 4. Apt/Suite/# 5. City. Give the following payload : "> and click on Place Order and there it goes 5 stored XSS will appear
vulnerability_information_html:
Occurred in the URL : https://store.ellislab.com/billing
After adding a product to the cart proceed to add the billing and card information and in the card fields give your card details respectively and in the fields

  1. First name
  2. Last name
  3. Street Address
  4. Apt/Suite/#
  5. City.

Give the following payload : "><img src=x onerror=prompt(0);> and click on Place Order and there it goes 5 stored XSS will appear

activities.message:
I believe you are referring to our website, [EllisLab.com](http://ellislab.com/), rather than our downloadable software application, [ExpressionEngine](https://store.ellislab.com/), but we do appreciate the report all the same.

Can you describe a POC that describes how an attack might be carried out in the real world? Seems like this would have to be self-inflicted, no?
activities.markdown_message:
I believe you are referring to our website, EllisLab.com, rather than our downloadable software application, ExpressionEngine, but we do appreciate the report all the same.

Can you describe a POC that describes how an attack might be carried out in the real world? Seems like this would have to be self-inflicted, no?

activities.message: Hi charan, thanks for the video. I understand how it works, but can you describe how this could be used by an attacker against a victim? I'm only seeing that they can run JS in context for themselves, which they could also do by opening up a developer console.
activities.markdown_message: Hi charan, thanks for the video. I understand how it works, but can you describe how this could be used by an attacker against a victim? I'm only seeing that they can run JS in context for themselves, which they could also do by opening up a developer console.

activities.message:
Hi djones,
Using this vulnerability the attacker can deface the entire website.
If the attacker injects a iframe tag  using  this vulnerability the entire website formats and layouts gets changed and the entire code gets damaged severely .
And the method to overcome these vulnerabilities is by securing the original code by using filters for the user input fields.
Hope you understood the severity of the bug..!!
Secure the code as soon as possible.

activities.message: But it only gets changed for the visitor himself. These fields are never displayed to anyone but the person to whom they belong to. Which would be the same as them using developer tools to deface/modify the markup that their browser is rendering. It would only be an attack if the attacker and victim are different visitors, no?
activities.markdown_message: But it only gets changed for the visitor himself. These fields are never displayed to anyone but the person to whom they belong to. Which would be the same as them using developer tools to deface/modify the markup that their browser is rendering. It would only be an attack if the attacker and victim are different visitors, no?

activities.message:
Hi djones,
Yes as u said the webpage is getting changed only for the visitor itself but you should not take it simple because the attacker can do all the following :


Attackers can do a lot when they can inject code into a page. For example, they can

1.    steal credentials in non-HTTPOnly cookies.
2.    send requests to a server with the user's credentials. Think XSRF
3.    steal secrets that are stored in JS variables.(Attacker can retrieve the code)
4.    prompt the user to download content by submitting a form.
5.    display text that seems to come from the site owners. Think phishing.
6.    display a password input, log keystrokes, and send the result to a site of your choosing.
7.    redirect to another site.(Defacing the website)

Reflected XSS Attacks: Reflected attacks are those where the injected code is reflected off the web server, such as in an error message, search result, or any other response that includes some or all of the input sent to the server as part of the request. Reflected attacks are delivered to victims via another route, such as in an e-mail message, or on some other web server like links or ads. When a user is tricked into clicking on a malicious link or submitting a specially crafted form, the injected code travels to the vulnerable web server, which reflects the attack back to the user’s browser. The browser then executes the code because it came from a "trusted" server.

I'm working as Information Security Analyst thats why i know the severity of this bug.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi djones,
Yes as u said the webpage is getting changed only for the visitor itself but you should not take it simple because the attacker can do all the following :

Attackers can do a lot when they can inject code into a page. For example, they can

  1. steal credentials in non-HTTPOnly cookies.
  2. send requests to a server with the user's credentials. Think XSRF
  3. steal secrets that are stored in JS variables.(Attacker can retrieve the code)
  4. prompt the user to download content by submitting a form.
  5. display text that seems to come from the site owners. Think phishing.
  6. display a password input, log keystrokes, and send the result to a site of your choosing.
  7. redirect to another site.(Defacing the website)

Reflected XSS Attacks: Reflected attacks are those where the injected code is reflected off the web server, such as in an error message, search result, or any other response that includes some or all of the input sent to the server as part of the request. Reflected attacks are delivered to victims via another route, such as in an e-mail message, or on some other web server like links or ads. When a user is tricked into clicking on a malicious link or submitting a specially crafted form, the injected code travels to the vulnerable web server, which reflects the attack back to the user’s browser. The browser then executes the code because it came from a "trusted" server.

I'm working as Information Security Analyst thats why i know the severity of this bug.

activities.message: Thank you charan. I am unable to reproduce. In watching your address bar, it looks as if the request to place the order is not being sent via AJAX, do you have have anything installed in your browser that is intercepting or changing POST requests? See attached video.
activities.markdown_message: Thank you charan. I am unable to reproduce. In watching your address bar, it looks as if the request to place the order is not being sent via AJAX, do you have have anything installed in your browser that is intercepting or changing POST requests? See attached video.

activities.message: Hi djones, Give your card details correctly and dont give the CVV correctly simply modify it. e.g if the CVV is 132 use 135. Have a look at the following video and use the payloads as follows: At first use the payload "> [XSS will not be prompted] Then you will notice some extra code text in the webpage, then do the above process as it is and use the following payload. " onmouseover = " prompt(0) in all the fields.And this time XSS will be prompted whenever the cursor is moved over the frields.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi djones,
Give your card details correctly and dont give the CVV correctly simply modify it. e.g if the CVV is 132 use 135.

Have a look at the following video and use the payloads as follows:
At first use the payload "><img src=x onerror=alert(0);> [XSS will not be prompted]
Then you will notice some extra code text in the webpage, then do the above process as it is and use the following payload.
" onmouseover = " prompt(0)
in all the fields.And this time XSS will be prompted whenever the cursor is moved over the frields.

activities.message: Ok, thanks for the additional info, charan. The bogus markup is not a concern to us, as it successfully stopped the exploit, but the cascading effect that allowed the script to run is obviously bad. I will try to update you in the next 24 hours.
activities.markdown_message: Ok, thanks for the additional info, charan. The bogus markup is not a concern to us, as it successfully stopped the exploit, but the cascading effect that allowed the script to run is obviously bad. I will try to update you in the next 24 hours.
